item.description:
Come hike in Ipswich River Wildlife Sanctuary, Mass Audubonâ€™s largest sanctuary at 2265 acres, which offers more than 10 miles of interconnecting trails through forests, meadows, and wetlands. The trail climbs the drumlin and esker, landscape features created by a glacier 15,000 years ago. We can also take a look at the huge rocks and exotic trees and shrubs that were part of a former arboretum. About 90 minutes - please bring yaktrax or snow shoes if there is snow or ice! Will cancel if there is a storm.

NO DOGS allowed here, sorry.

There is an admission charge of $4 for the sanctuary but it's free if you are a Mass Audubon current member.


Directions:
From Boston and the south: Take Rt I-95 north to exit 50 and follow Rt 1 north. At the junction of Rt 1 and Rt 97, turn right onto Rt 97 south (toward Beverly and Danvers). Follow Rt 97 south and take the third left onto Perkins Row. Follow Perkins Row for 1 mile, and the sanctuary is on the right.

From the north: Take Rt I-95 south to exit 53A and follow Rt 97 south. At the junction of Rt 1 and Rt 97 in Topsfield, stay on Rt 97 south and take the third left onto Perkins Row. Follow Perkins Row for 1 mile, and the sanctuary is on the right.

group.name: North Shore Not Too Intense Hikers

item.name: Ipswich River Wildlife Sanctuary walk, Topsfield
